project.name: GrapeFruit Game Engine
project.description: A fun and easy WebGL-enabled JavaScript Game Engine

AudioManager.name: AudioManager
AudioManager.description:
Grapefruit Audio API, provides an easy interface to use WebAudoiAPI with a fallback to HTML5 Audio
The GF Audio API was originally based on [Howler.js](https://github.com/goldfire/howler.js)
Generally you will use this via the `game.audio` or `state.audio` properties.

params.name: game
params.description: The game instance this manager belongs to

params.name: parent
params.description:
The parent audio manager this manager belongs to.
     This is used to create a web audio API node heirarchy.

AudioPlayer.name: AudioPlayer
AudioPlayer.description:
Grapefruit Audio API, provides an easy interface to use HTML5 Audio
The GF Audio API was based on [Howler.js](https://github.com/goldfire/howler.js)

params.name: manager
params.description: AudioManager instance for this audio player

params.name: audio
params.description: The preloaded audio file object

props.name: data
props.description: The actual audio data

props.name: webAudio
props.description: Whether the file is using webAudio or not

props.name: decoded
props.description: Whether the data has been decoded yet or not

params.name: settings
params.description: All the settings for this player instance

props.name: autoplay
props.description: Whether to automatically start playing the audio file

props.name: loop
props.description: Whether the audio should loop or not

props.name: pos3d
props.description: The 3d position of the audio to play in the form [x, y, z]

props.name: sprite
props.description:
The audio sprite, if this audio clip has multiple sounds in it.
     This object is in the form `{ 'sound': [start, duration] }`, and you can use them with `.play('sound')`.

Camera.name: Camera
Camera.description:
A basic Camera object that provides some effects. It also will contain the GUI
to ensure they are using "screen-coords".

params.name: state
params.description: The game state this camera belongs to

BaseTexture.name: BaseTexture
BaseTexture.description:
A texture stores the information that represents an image. All textures have a base texture
*This is directly exposing [PIXI.BaseTexture](http://www.goodboydigital.com/pixijs/docs/classes/BaseTexture.html)*

params.name: source
params.description: the source object (image or canvas)

Container.name: Container
Container.description:
The base display object, that anything being put on the screen inherits from
Container or Sprite at some point. This class extends PIXI's DisplayObjectContainer.

Graphics.name: Graphics
Graphics.description:
The Graphics class contains a set of methods that you can use to create primitive shapes and lines. 
It is important to know that with the webGL renderer only simple polys can be filled at this stage
Complex polys will not be filled. Heres an example of a
[complex polygon](http://www.goodboydigital.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/complexPolygon.png).
*This is directly exposing [PIXI.Graphics](http://www.goodboydigital.com/pixijs/docs/classes/Graphics.html)*

RenderTexture.name: RenderTexture

params.name: width
params.description: The width of the render texture

params.name: height
params.description: The height of the render texture

Sprite.name: Sprite
Sprite.description: The base Sprite class. This class is the base for all images on the screen. This class extends PIXI's Sprite.

params.name: textures
params.description:
The texture for the sprite to display, an array of texture to animation through, or an animation object.
     The later looks like: `{ animationName: { frames: [frame1, frame2], speed: 0.5, loop: false } }` where each frame is a Texture object

params.name: speed
params.description: The speed of the animations (can be overriden on a specific animations)

params.name: start
params.description: The animation to start with, defaults to the first found key otherwise

Texture.name: Texture
Texture.description:
A texture stores the information that represents an image or part of an image. It cannot be added
to the display list directly. It is used to desribe how a Sprite looks. If no frame is provided
then the whole image is used.
*This is directly exposing [PIXI.Texture](http://www.goodboydigital.com/pixijs/docs/classes/Texture.html)*
though it does add some extra methods.

params.name: baseTexture
params.description: The base texture source to create the texture from

params.name: frame
params.description: The rectangle frame of the texture to show

TilingSprite.name: TilingSprite
TilingSprite.description:
A tiling sprite is a fast way of rendering a tiling image
*This is directly exposing [PIXI.TilingSprite](http://www.goodboydigital.com/pixijs/docs/classes/TilingSprite.html)*

params.name: texture
params.description: the texture of the tiling sprite

params.name: width
params.description: the width of the tiling sprite

params.name: height
params.description: the height of the tiling sprite

fx.camera.Close.name: fx.camera.Close
fx.camera.Close.description:
Close camera effect. This effect creates a mask on the world that will animated to cover
the screen working from the outside-in. It is like a camera shutter "closing" around the target

fx.camera.Fade.name: fx.camera.Fade
fx.camera.Fade.description:
Fade the screen into a color. This will fade into a color that will
eventually cover the screen.

fx.camera.Flash.name: fx.camera.Flash
fx.camera.Flash.description:
Flash the screen with a color. This will cover the screen in a
color then fade it out.

fx.camera.Scanlines.name: fx.camera.Scanlines
fx.camera.Scanlines.description: Adds arcade-style scanlines to the camera viewport.

fx.camera.Shake.name: fx.camera.Shake
fx.camera.Shake.description: Shakes the camera around a bit.

Game.name: Game
Game.description: Main game object, controls the entire instance of the game

params.name: container
params.description: The container for the new canvas we will create for the game, or the ID of one

params.name: settings
params.description: All the settings for the game instance

props.name: width
props.description: The width of the viewport

props.name: height
props.description: The height of the viewport

props.name: renderer
props.description: The renderer to use either RENDERER.AUTO, RENDERER.CANVAS, or RENDERER.WEBGL

props.name: transparent
props.description: Should the render element have a transparent background

props.name: background
props.description: The background color of the stage

props.name: antialias
props.description: Anti-alias graphics (in WebGL this helps with edges, in Canvas2D it retains pixel-art quality)

props.name: canvas
props.description: The canvas to render into, if not specified one is created

State.name: State
State.description: States are containers that represent different states of a game

params.name: game
params.description: The game instance this state belongs to

params.name: name
params.description: The name of this state

params.name: physicsOptions
params.description: All the settings for the physics environment

props.name: gravity
props.description: The gravity constant for the physics system (default is 9.87, which is normal Earth gravity)

StateManager.name: StateManager
StateManager.description: A state manager is a container for all the states in a game.

params.name: game
params.description: The game this manager bleongs to.

World.name: World
World.description: The world is the container for all game objects in a game state.

Circle.name: Circle
Circle.description:
The Circle object is an area defined by its position, as indicated by its
center point (x, y) and by its radius.

params.name: center
params.description: The point of the center of the circle

params.name: radius
params.description: The radius of the circle

Ellipse.name: Ellipse
Ellipse.description:
The Ellipse object can be used to specify a hit area for displayobjects
see [PIXI.Ellipse](http://www.goodboydigital.com/pixijs/docs/classes/Ellipse.html)
for more information.

params.name: x
params.description: The X coord of the upper-left corner of the framing rectangle of this ellipse

params.name: y
params.description: The Y coord of the upper-left corner of the framing rectangle of this ellipse

params.name: width
params.description: The overall height of this ellipse

params.name: height
params.description: The overall width of this ellipse

params.name: x
params.description: The X origin of the polygon, all X coords for all points are relative to this

params.name: y
params.description: The Y origin of the polygon, all Y coords for all points are relative to this

params.name: points
params.description:
This can be an array of Vectors that form the polygon,
     a flat array of numbers that will be interpreted as [x,y, x,y, ...]

params.name: scale
params.description: The scale of the polygon

Rectangle.name: Rectangle
Rectangle.description:
The Rectangle object is an area defined by its position, as indicated by its
top-left corner point (x, y) and by its width and its height.

params.name: x
params.description: The X coord of the upper-left corner of the rectangle

params.name: y
params.description: The Y coord of the upper-left corner of the rectangle

params.name: width
params.description: The overall wisth of this rectangle

params.name: height
params.description: The overall height of this rectangle

GuiItem.name: GuiItem
GuiItem.description: The base GuiItem that represents an element of a gui on the screen.

params.name: texture
params.description: The texture to set the sprite to

params.name: interactive
params.description: Whether this item should repsond to mouse events

Pointer.name: Pointer
Pointer.description: Represents a single pointer input method

params.name: id
params.description: The identifier for this pointer

params.name: manager
params.description: The pointer manager for this pointer instance

Input.name: Input
Input.description: The base Input object, holds common functions and properties between input types

params.name: game
params.description: The game instance this input belongs to

InputManager.name: InputManager
InputManager.description: Manages all input handlers in a unified way

params.name: game
params.description: The game instance this input belongs to

params.name: game
params.description: The game instance this input belongs to

Pointers.name: Pointers
Pointers.description: Controls pointer input (mouse, touch, pen, etc) or all pointers tracked by the game

params.name: game
params.description: The game instance this input belongs to

Loader.name: Loader
Loader.description:
The Loader loads and parses different game assets, such as sounds, textures,
TMX World files (exported from the [Tiled Editor](http://mapeditor.org)),
and Sprite Atlas files (published from [Texture Packer](http://www.codeandweb.com/texturepacker)).

params.name: game
params.description: Game instance this belongs to

Vector.name: Vector
Vector.description:
A 2d Vector implementation stolen directly from mrdoob's THREE.js
[Vector2d](https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/master/src/math/Vector2.js)

params.name: x
params.description: The x component of the vector

params.name: y
params.description: The y component of the vector

math.name: math
math.description: The grapefruit math library, used to abstract commonly used math operations

ParticleEmitter.name: ParticleEmitter
ParticleEmitter.description:
The ParticleEmitter is the object that is placed in the world and will fire off particles based
on the rules and properties set on it. Generally you will want to create/use these by adding
them to a ParticleSystem.

params.name: name
params.description: The string name of the particle emitter.

ParticleSystem.name: ParticleSystem
ParticleSystem.description:
The ParticleSystem controls the system of particle emitters and their particles. It contains all the emitters
and updates them each frame. An instance of this is created for you in a world instance, which is a property
of a game state. The general usage for this class is:

PhysicsSystem.name: PhysicsSystem
PhysicsSystem.description:
The PhysicsSystem is the wrapper around the chipmunk-js physics library that integrates
grapefruit objects into the physics world. It is in charge of managing objects in the physics
space. Generally you would not create this yourself and instead would use the `.physics` property
of a State.

params.name: state
params.description: The state instance this system belongs to.

params.name: options
params.description: The options for the physics system.

params.name: [options.gravity=new
params.description: Vector(0, 9.87)]  The gravity of the space

PhysicsTarget.name: PhysicsTarget
PhysicsTarget.description: Physics mixin. This will add physics capabilities to the class it mixes into.

BitmapText.name: BitmapText
BitmapText.description:
A Text Object will create (a) line(s) of text using bitmap font. To split a line you can use "\n", "\r" or "\r\n"
You can generate the fnt files using [bmfont](http://www.angelcode.com/products/bmfont/) for windows or
[bmglyph](http://www.bmglyph.com/) for mac.

params.name: text
params.description: The copy that you would like the text to display

params.name: font
params.description: The font data object (this is generally grabbed from `game.cache.getBitmapFont('mykey')`);

props.name: name
props.description: The name of the font

props.name: size
props.description: The base size of the font

props.name: lineHeight
props.description: The line height of the font

props.name: chars
props.description: The characters in the font, each should have a texture and kerning info

params.name: style
params.description: The style parameters

props.name: size
props.description: The font size of the text, overrides the font's size

props.name: align
props.description: An alignment of the multiline text ("left", "center" or "right")

Text.name: Text
Text.description: A Text Object will create a line(s) of text to split a line you can use "\n" see PIXI.Text for more information.

params.name: text
params.description: The copy that you would like the text to display

params.name: style
params.description: The style parameters

props.name: font
props.description: default "bold 20pt Arial" The style and size of the font

props.name: fill
props.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text eg "red", "#00FF00"

props.name: align
props.description: An alignment of the multiline text ("left", "center" or "right")

props.name: stroke
props.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text stroke eg "blue", "#FCFF00"

props.name: strokeThickness
props.description: A number that represents the thickness of the stroke. Default is 0 (no stroke)

props.name: wordWrap
props.description: Indicates if word wrap should be used

props.name: wordWrapWidth
props.description: The width at which text will wrap

ObjectGroup.name: ObjectGroup
ObjectGroup.description:
Tiled object group is a special layer that contains entities
TODO: This is all trash

params.name: map
params.description: The tilemap instance that this belongs to

params.name: group
params.description: All the settings for the layer

Tile.name: Tile
Tile.description: Base Tile implementation, a tile is a single tile in a tilemap layer

params.name: texture
params.description: The texture of the tile

Tilelayer.name: Tilelayer
Tilelayer.description:
The Tilelayer is the visual tiled layer that actually displays on the screen

This class will be created by the Tilemap, there shouldn't be a reason to
create an instance on your own.

params.name: map
params.description: The tilemap instance that this belongs to

params.name: layer
params.description: All the settings for the layer

Tilemap.name: Tilemap
Tilemap.description:
Tiled map that represents an entire tile map with multiple layers or object groups.
Often it is easier to create a tilemap using the object factor on a world, rather
than doing it manually yourself.

params.name: state
params.description: The game state the map belongs to

params.name: map
params.description: All the settings for the map

params.name: tilesetTextures
params.description:
An object whose keys are the tileset name,
     and whose values are the textures for the tileset. For example:
     `{ tileset1: new Texture(), ... }`

Tileset.name: Tileset
Tileset.description:
This object represents a tileset used by a Tilemap.
There can be multiple Tilesets in a map

params.name: texture
params.description: The texture to use for the tileset

params.name: settings
params.description: All the settings for the tileset

props.name: tilewidth
props.description: The width of a single tile in the set

props.name: tileheight
props.description: The height of a single tile in the set

props.name: firstgid
props.description: The id of the first tile in the set, defaults to 1

props.name: spacing
props.description: The spacing around tiles in the tileset (in pixels)

props.name: margin
props.description: The margin around a tile in the tileset (in pixels)

props.name: tileoffset
props.description: The offset to apply to a tile rendered from this tileset

props.name: x
props.description: The X offset to apply to the tile

props.name: y
props.description: The Y offset to apply to the tile

props.name: properties
props.description: User-defined, custom properties that apply to the tileset

props.name: tileproperties
props.description:
User-defined, custom properties that apply to tiles in the tileset.
         The keys of this object should the tile id of the properties

props.name: imagewidth
props.description: An override for the image width

props.name: imageheight
props.description: An override for the image height

Cache.name: Cache
Cache.description:
A game only has one instance of a Cache and it is used to store all externally loaded assets such
as images, sounds and data files as a result of Loader calls. Cache items use string based keys for look-up.

params.name: game
params.description: The game instance this cache belongs to

Clock.name: Clock
Clock.description:
High performance clock, based on mrdoob's
[Three.js clock](https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/master/src/core/Clock.js),
but with tweaks.

EventEmitter.name: EventEmitter
EventEmitter.description:
Event emitter mixin. This will add emitter properties to an object so that
it can emit events, and have others listen for them. Based on
[node.js event emitter](https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/lib/events.js)

ObjectFactory.name: ObjectFactory
ObjectFactory.description:
The object factory makes it simple to create and add objects to a parent. One is added
to a State's world and camera by default, but they can be used for any parent but they
can only belong to a single state.

params.name: state
params.description: The game state this factory belongs to

params.name: parent
params.description: The container to act as the parent for created objects

ObjectPool.name: ObjectPool
ObjectPool.description:
Holds a pool of different Objects to help reduce the number times
an object is created and destroyed.

params.name: type
params.description: The object type that this pool will hold (like Sprite, or Tile)

params.name: parent
params.description:
The parent that the objects will be added to. Passing this in will
     make the pool add any newly created objects as children to this object.

SpritePool.name: SpritePool
SpritePool.description:
Holds a pool of different Sprites that can be created, makes it very
easy to quickly create different registered entities

params.name: game
params.description: The game instance this sprite pool belongs to

support.name: support
support.description:
Holds the results of the feature detection run on the browser, to make it simple to
see which features the library can use.

utils.name: utils
utils.description: The grapefruit utility object, used for misc functions used throughout the code base

RENDERER.name: RENDERER
RENDERER.description:
The types of renderers supported. These are generally passed in to the constructor of
a {{#crossLink "Game"}}{{/crossLink}} instance.

FILE_FORMAT.name: FILE_FORMAT
FILE_FORMAT.description: The types of files that the loader supports for types that have multiple formats (like tilemaps).

ATLAS_FORMAT.name: ATLAS_FORMAT
ATLAS_FORMAT.description: The types of texture atlas file formats that the loader supports.

CAMERA_FOLLOW.name: CAMERA_FOLLOW
CAMERA_FOLLOW.description: The follow types that the camera can execute

AXIS.name: AXIS
AXIS.description: These represent different axis. They are bitwise flags and can be combined together.

DIRECTION.name: DIRECTION
DIRECTION.description: These represent different directions in the world. They are bitwise flags and can be combined together.

pkg.name: pkg
pkg.description:
The pkg object contains all the grapefruit package information from package.json,
inserted at build time.

plugin.name: plugin
plugin.description: Provides methods for patching core functions, and registering plugins.

classitems.description:
Set the 3D position of the audio source.
The most common usage is to set the 'x' position
to affect the left/right ear panning. Setting any value higher than
1.0 will begin to decrease the volume of the sound as it moves further away.
NOTE: This only works with Web Audio API, HTML5 Audio playback
will not be affected.
classitems.name: setPosition

params.name: x
params.description: The x-position of the playback from -1000.0 to 1000.0

params.name: y
params.description: The y-position of the playback from -1000.0 to 1000.0

params.name: z

classitems.description:
Adds a particle emitter to the system, creating one if necessary.

There are 3 ways to use this function to add an emitter to the system. The simplest case
is to pass a string for the name, and let the manager create a normal gf.ParticleEmitter for you
with the name you provided. The second usage is to pass a class that is a decendant of gf.ParticleEmitter.

For example:

```
function MyEmitter(name) {
    gf.ParticleEmitter.call(name);
}
gf.inherit(MyEmitter, gf.ParticleEmitter);

game.world.particles.add(MyEmitter); //adds a new instance of your emitter
```

The final usage is to pass an Emitter that is already created. In this case the system will
add the emitter to the list based on `emitter.name`.
classitems.name: add

params.name: emitter
params.description: The emitter name, constructor, or emitter instance to add.

params.description: The name of the emitter to remove, or the emitter instance itself.

classitems.description:
Parses an array of numbers that represent a hitArea into the actual shape.

For example: `[1, 1, 15]` is a Circle (`[x, y, radius]`); `[1, 1, 15, 15]` is a Rectangle
(`[x, y, width, height]`); and any length >= 5 is a polygon in the form `[x1, y1, x2, y2, ..., xN, yN]`.
classitems.name: parseHitArea

params.name: value
params.description: The array to parse

classitems.description:
Parses an object of string properties into potential javascript types. First it attempts to
convert to a number, if that fails it checks for the string 'true' or 'false' and changes it
to the actual Boolean value, then it attempts to parse a string as JSON.

params.description: The array to parse
